thread.title: Bill Maher endorses Bernie Sanders, 'I want to see you be president'
thread.title_full: Bill Maher endorses Bernie Sanders, 'I want to see you be president' | Examiner.com

author: Robert Sobel
title: Bill Maher endorses Bernie Sanders, 'I want to see you be president'
text:
Play Sen. Bernie Sanders picks up an endorsement during his latest appearance on HBO's "Real Time." youtube.com Just days after the first Democratic debate and most voters are locked on Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders . While most media pundits declared Clinton the winner, the overwhelming consensus among liberal voters on social media was that Sanders was victorious.
youtube.com The divide between liberals and Democratic voters reached a fear pitch on Tuesday night during the debate . Supporters of Clinton and Sanders battled on Facebook and Twitter, showcasing that the party is not as united as some might have believed. Though Clinton is still the front runner, Sanders has surprised many with his rise in the polls. During the Oct. 16 edition of HBO's "Real Time with Bill Maher," the independent senator from Vermont picked up a new endorsement.
Sanders joined Maher as he was greeted with a standing ovation from the Los Angeles crowd. Less than a minute into their conversation and Maher made it clear who he was supporting for president.
"I want to help your campaign. I want to see you get the nomination. I want to see you be president."
The conversation was not a fluff piece by Maher, who pushed the senator to delve deeper into his policies, and how he would pay for them. The "Real Time" host pressed Sanders for a more accurate explanation into what socialism really was. While Sanders did list multiple examples of the programs he wants to bring to life, and how to cover the cost, he failed to give a detailed explanation of how his agenda would realistically unfold.
Maher expressed concern for the strong possibility that Sanders would be unable to win key primary states in more moderate areas. Disagreeing, Sanders explained that he receives nearly 25 percent of the Republican vote in his state of Vermont, but Maher didn't appear to be convinced. "You could get Republicans?" Maher asked, stating, "Even the toss-up states that Obama barely won?."
The former Secretary of State is still holding large leads in most national polls, but Sanders has closed the gap, especially in two important states, Iowa and New Hampshire. With the next debate less than a month away, Sanders can add Maher's name to the list of supporters who are "Feeling the Bern."
